(M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14).proposition: COMPLAINT FOR BREACH OF THE COVENANT OF QUIET ENJOYMENT (M.G.L. c. 186, § 14)

**G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 231, § 1**, as the cause of action arose within the territorial jurisdiction of the Somerville District Court.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 231, § 1**, as the cause of action arose within the territorial jurisdiction of the Somerville District Court.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: A landlord’s **failure to take reasonable steps** to prevent or abate disturbances substantially interfering with a tenant’s use of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment not only by intentional acts, but also where substantial interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do, and where the landlord had the ability to control and abate the objectionable conditions but did not do so effectively. The opinion rejects a strict malfeasance/nonfeasance distinction and emphasizes the landlord’s responsibility to take steps to control disturbances that substantially interfere with tenants’ use, thus supporting the stated proposition.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, **371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent…”

*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease and is **non‑waivable** by the tenant.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly states that every tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not address whether that covenant is non‑waivable by the tenant. The court discusses the statutory and common‑law content of the right and the landlord’s liability standard, not the enforceability of any lease clause purporting to waive or limit the tenant’s quiet enjoyment rights. Because the non‑waivability issue is not analyzed or decided, the case does not support that part of the proposition.
*Simon v. Solomon*, **385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ — words that have little inherent meaning but a rich background in decisional law — it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 8.proposition: Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease and is **non‑waivable** by the tenant.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion describes G.L. c. 186, § 14 as codifying the common‑law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not discuss whether the covenant is non‑waivable or whether a tenant can contractually waive it. The only mention of waiver-related concepts is a footnote referencing that landlords may limit liability for natural causes, which actually suggests some degree of permissibility for contractual limitation, cutting against an inference of absolute non‑waivability. Thus, the case neither addresses nor supports the specific claim that the right is non‑waivable in every residential lease.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, **424 Mass. 8.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). … We also observed that G. L. c. 186, § 14, permits landlords to provide in lease contracts that they are not liable for conditions resulting from natural causes beyond their control and that this provision ‘suggests that liability was not intended to be absolute.’ Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101 n.6 (1982).”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: (failure to address persistent conditions causing loss of enjoyment constitutes breach);
*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The case holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an essential service—constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, regardless of financial ability, and that injunctive relief and damages are appropriate. However, the opinion does not frame this as a generalized rule about “persistent conditions causing loss of enjoyment,” nor does it discuss a broader duty to address all such conditions; it is specifically about failure to furnish heat. Thus it only indirectly, and not expressly, supports the broader proposition as stated.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, **13 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

*Brown v. LeClair*, **20 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: (landlord responsible for failure to control other tenants creating disturbances);
*Brown v. LeClair*, **20 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with landlord liability for physical conditions of the premises (leaks, roaches, flooding, and an insecure, flimsy door that allowed an intruder to assault the tenant), but it does not discuss the landlord’s duty to control or restrain other tenants who create disturbances. The assault is tied to a code-violating door, not to any independent obligation to manage or police other tenants’ behavior. Thus, the case does not establish or analyze a rule about landlord responsibility for failing to control other tenants’ disturbances.
*Brown v. LeClair*, **20 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “These damages were based on a September, 1980, incident in which LeClair was assaulted with a knife by a neighbor after the neighbor punched a hole through LeClair’s hollow core front door and entered his apartment. The judge found that the construction of the door to LeClair’s apartment did not provide adequate security and was in violation of the State Sanitary Code…. There was evidence that the door was of flimsy construction. The question whether the requisite causal connection has been shown is one of fact.”

*Keegan v. MacDonald*, **27 Mass. App. C.proposition: (interference need not be direct to constitute breach);
*Keegan v. MacDonald*, **27 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The provided text is actually from a criminal case involving suppression of narcotics evidence and probable cause for arrest and search. It does not concern contract law, interference, or breach, nor does it discuss any principle that interference need not be direct to constitute a breach. Therefore, this opinion does not support the stated proposition about interference and breach.
*Keegan v. MacDonald*, **27 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: "In our view the Commonwealth sustained its burden to show that the officers acted on probable cause, that is, a 'requirement . . . satisfied by showing facts which would warrant a man of reasonable caution in believing that certain action is appropriate.'"

*Jablonski v. Casey*, **64 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: (covenant breached when landlord fails to maintain peaceable conditions);
*Jablonski v. Casey*, **64 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment but frames it as protection from “serious interference with her tenancy,” not as a general duty to “maintain peaceable conditions.” The court finds no breach where the landlord promptly remedied physical defects and there was “no evidence … of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment.” It does not articulate or apply a rule that the covenant is breached whenever a landlord fails to maintain peaceable conditions in a broader sense (e.g., disturbances), so it does not support that specific proposition.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, **64 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition. … We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. Co.raw_text: *Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. Co.*, **316 Mass. 626 (1944)**
*Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. Co.proposition: (quiet enjoyment guarantees lawful possession free from interference);
*Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. Co.case_name: Damiano v. National Grange Mutual Liability Co.
*Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. Co.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an insurer’s contractual duty to defend its insured in a liability policy and the sufficiency of the plaintiff’s declaration against a demurrer. It does not discuss leases, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or any doctrine that ‘quiet enjoyment guarantees lawful possession free from interference.’ Therefore, it provides no authority for the stated quiet enjoyment proposition and appears to be mis-cited for that point.
*Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. Co.relevant_excerpt: "The basis of the alleged duty of the defendant is an agreement contained in the policy. Abrams v. Factory Mutual Liability Ins. Co. 298 Mass. 141, 144. The plaintiff’s cause of action arises out of the breach of that agreement. ‘By the express terms of the policy the defendant obligated itself to defend lawsuits. If it did not settle, it was bound to defend.’"

*Reis v. Miller*, **19 Mass. L. Rptr. 23.raw_text: *Reis v. Miller*, **19 Mass. L. Rptr. 233 (Mass. Super. Ct. 2005)**
*Reis v. Miller*, **19 Mass. L. Rptr. 23.proposition: (noise complaints ignored by landlord establish violation);
*Reis v. Miller*, **19 Mass. L. Rptr. 23.case_name: Welch Foods, Inc. v. Liberty Mutual Fire Insurance
*Reis v. Miller*, **19 Mass. L. Rptr. 23.support_reasoning: The opinion is an insurance coverage dispute between Welch and Liberty Mutual concerning duty to defend under a commercial general liability policy. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, noise complaints, or any theory that a landlord’s ignoring tenants’ noise complaints constitutes a statutory or common-law violation. Nothing in the facts, reasoning, or holding touches on landlord liability for noise complaints, so the case cannot support that proposition.
*Reis v. Miller*, **19 Mass. L. Rptr. 23.relevant_excerpt:
The policy enumerates coverage for certain personal injuries identified by the conduct of the insured including, inter alia, injury arising out of: (1) malicious prosecution; (2) oral or written publication of material that slanders or libels a person or organization or disparages a person’s or organization’s goods, products or services, and/or (3) wrongful entry into a room, dwelling or premises that the person occupies.

… Liberty Mutual had a duty to defend Welch against Cadbury’s trespass claim.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.proposition: (damages may include emotional distress and inconvenience caused by interference).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on rent abatement as the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability, calculated as the difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and in its defective condition. It does not discuss or authorize recovery for emotional distress, annoyance, or inconvenience; the only damages mentioned are economic (rent abatement). Therefore, it does not support the proposition that damages may include emotional distress and inconvenience caused by the interference.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, **37.relevant_excerpt: “The trial judge found that the measure of damages was ‘the difference between the value of the apartment as warranted and the rental value of the apartment in its defective condition.’ See McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 306 (1977). Apart from the question whether the tenant’s rent abates only after the landlord has had a reasonable time to repair, damages are not in dispute in this case.”

*Meikle v. Nurse*, **474 Mass. 207 (2016.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to statutory damages equal to three months’ rent ($4,500) or her actual damages—estimated at $2,000 plus ongoing losses—whichever is greater, as well as costs and reasonable attorney’s fees (even if self‑represented, courts may award reasonable fees under *Meikle v. Nurse*, **474 Mass. 207 (2016)**).
*Meikle v. Nurse*, **474 Mass. 207 (2016.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with whether a tenant can use violations of the Massachusetts security deposit statute as a defense to possession in a summary process action and how G.L. c. 239, § 8A operates. It does not set or discuss any measure of statutory damages (e.g., three months’ rent) or actual damages, nor does it address attorney’s fees for self‑represented litigants or otherwise under G.L. c. 186, § 15B. The reference to treble damages, costs, and attorney’s fees is purely descriptive of the statute, not a holding about their availability or calculation, and nothing in the excerpt suggests courts may award attorney’s fees to pro se parties under this case.
*Meikle v. Nurse*, **474 Mass. 207 (2016.relevant_excerpt: “Our cases involving the security deposit statute demonstrate its importance in the scheme of protections afforded a tenant. This court has recognized for some time that the Legislature views violations of the security deposit statute, G. L. c. 186, § 15B, as serious violations… Indeed, the security deposit statute provides for treble damages, costs, and attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 15B (7). Thus, it would be contrary to legislative intent to interpret ‘violation of any other law’ in a manner that would undermine a tenant’s right to assert the range of protections available under the summary process statute.”
